content.raw: related: https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/policy/CMP0048.html
content.html: related: https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.0/policy/CMP0048.html

content.raw:
This is genuinely mysterious to me, because we're very explicitly setting the cmake version to 3.5.1 as indicated [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/09bb73986646e2acad9c822c526311132cb48b31/CMakeLists.txt?at=ign-cmake_appveyor&fileviewer=file-view-default#CMakeLists.txt-1).

According to cmake's documentation (which you linked), it should happily use the `NEW` policy of `CMP0048` and set the versions as we expect. Or else, if Appveyor is using a version of cmake which is older than 3.5.1, cmake should quit right away.
content.html:
This is genuinely mysterious to me, because we're very explicitly setting the cmake version to 3.5.1 as indicated here.

According to cmake's documentation (which you linked), it should happily use the NEW policy of CMP0048 and set the versions as we expect. Or else, if Appveyor is using a version of cmake which is older than 3.5.1, cmake should quit right away.

content.raw:
This raises some really bizarre questions, like when exactly is the vcpkg toolchain being run? The policy is already set to `NEW` before we even touch it, which would imply that whatever impact the vcpkg toolchain is having is taking place after our script begins executing but before we reach the call to `project(~)`. Unless this is some kind of cmake bug where the call to `project(~)` is simply neglecting to abide by the policy settings.

We could try putting those same debug lines (where we print out the policy, set the policy, and print it out again) into a branch of ignition-cmake just before the call to `project(~)`, and test the build of this ignition-math branch against that. If that doesn't fix it, then I have to view this as a bug in cmake.
content.html:
This raises some really bizarre questions, like when exactly is the vcpkg toolchain being run? The policy is already set to NEW before we even touch it, which would imply that whatever impact the vcpkg toolchain is having is taking place after our script begins executing but before we reach the call to project(~). Unless this is some kind of cmake bug where the call to project(~) is simply neglecting to abide by the policy settings.

We could try putting those same debug lines (where we print out the policy, set the policy, and print it out again) into a branch of ignition-cmake just before the call to project(~), and test the build of this ignition-math branch against that. If that doesn't fix it, then I have to view this as a bug in cmake.

content.raw: Nothing sticks out in the [CMake 3.9 docs for policies](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.9/manual/cmake-policies.7.html). They mention policy settings may not affect parent scope in some cases, but this seems like it's not propagating to a child scope.
content.html: Nothing sticks out in the CMake 3.9 docs for policies. They mention policy settings may not affect parent scope in some cases, but this seems like it's not propagating to a child scope.

content.raw: Since `ign_configure_project` is a macro, there shouldn't even be a change in scope at all.
content.html: Since ign_configure_project is a macro, there shouldn't even be a change in scope at all.

content.raw:
I think

["Commands created by the function() and macro() commands record policy settings when they are created and use the pre-record policies when they are invoked."](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.9/command/cmake_policy.html#cmake-policy-stack). 

combined with 

[" In CMake 2.6.3 and above, include() and find_package() by default PUSH and POP an entry on the policy stack around an included script"](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.9/policy/CMP0011.html)

means during `find_package(ign-cmake)` the cmake code ran with a clean policy slate, and the ign_configure_project macro is using those settings which don't have CMP0048 set.
content.html:
I think

"Commands created by the function() and macro() commands record policy settings when they are created and use the pre-record policies when they are invoked.".

combined with

" In CMake 2.6.3 and above, include() and find_package() by default PUSH and POP an entry on the policy stack around an included script"

means during find_package(ign-cmake) the cmake code ran with a clean policy slate, and the ign_configure_project macro is using those settings which don't have CMP0048 set.

content.raw: Seems like all we can do is suppress the warning using `-Wextended-offsetof`, because [a standard-compliant version of `offsetof(~)` won't be available until C++17](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/types/offsetof).
content.html: Seems like all we can do is suppress the warning using -Wextended-offsetof, because a standard-compliant version of offsetof(~) won't be available until C++17.

content.raw: accept both 3 and 4?
content.html: accept both 3 and 4?

content.raw: if we accept 3, then we have to keep using the old cmake variables instead of linking directly to targets. I usually advocate smooth transitions, but I'd be ok with moving straight to versions that use ignition-cmake to keep things tidy
content.html: if we accept 3, then we have to keep using the old cmake variables instead of linking directly to targets. I usually advocate smooth transitions, but I'd be ok with moving straight to versions that use ignition-cmake to keep things tidy

content.raw:
Technically, 3 was already exporting its targets and disguising them with `IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARIES`, so when you'd call `target_link_libraries(myTarget ${IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARIES})` you were secretly linking to the imported target rather than the traditional library paths.

We could hypothetically support both here without any loss of quality for users; it would just involve more upkeep for us to script in the logic of choosing between the two.
content.html:
Technically, 3 was already exporting its targets and disguising them with IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARIES, so when you'd call target_link_libraries(myTarget ${IGNITION-MATH_LIBRARIES}) you were secretly linking to the imported target rather than the traditional library paths.

We could hypothetically support both here without any loss of quality for users; it would just involve more upkeep for us to script in the logic of choosing between the two.

content.raw: Ok, if it's helpful, we can do it. I just wanted to make sure the benefits outweigh the costs
content.html: Ok, if it's helpful, we can do it. I just wanted to make sure the benefits outweigh the costs

content.html: I'm in favor of keeping things simple and only supporting ign-math4 here. Downstream packages (such as transport and gazebo) can also use ign-math4.

content.raw:
This is a pretty normal compiler warning.

If this is occurring in our own code, I'd recommend we actually do as it suggests and add a `default` case to the switches that it's complaining about, even if the default is just printing out an error message or doing nothing at all.

If this is occurring in the headers of external code that we depend on (like protobuf or gtest) then we should include those headers with the `SYSTEM` tag to suppress their warnings.

If that seems like too much work, we can add `-Wno-switch-default` to the compile options of `ign-cmake`. Or you can use `target_compile_options(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} -Wno-switch-default)` in your own project to just suppress it for yourself. I would discourage doing this, since it's a pretty reasonable warning for us to heed.
content.html:
This is a pretty normal compiler warning.

If this is occurring in our own code, I'd recommend we actually do as it suggests and add a default case to the switches that it's complaining about, even if the default is just printing out an error message or doing nothing at all.

If this is occurring in the headers of external code that we depend on (like protobuf or gtest) then we should include those headers with the SYSTEM tag to suppress their warnings.

If that seems like too much work, we can add -Wno-switch-default to the compile options of ign-cmake. Or you can use target_compile_options(${PROJECT_LIBRARY_TARGET_NAME} -Wno-switch-default) in your own project to just suppress it for yourself. I would discourage doing this, since it's a pretty reasonable warning for us to heed.

content.raw: Oooof, that's an interesting dilemma. It's an unfortunate workaround, since it will also suppress any cases where we leave out the `default` in our own `ign-msgs` code, but I can't think of a better short-term solution. The long-term solution would probably be to report an issue and/or make a pull request to `protobuf` :sweat_smile:

content.html:
Should this line be:

ignition-math4::ignition-math4 instead?

Or even better:

ignition-math${IGN_MATH_VER}::ignition-math${IGN_MATH_VER})

and use in the main CMakelists.txt:

#--------------------------------------
# Find ignition-math
set(IGN_MATH_VER 4)
ign_find_package(ignition-math${IGN_MATH_VER} REQUIRED)

content.raw:
Just to add some commentary to this suggestion for anyone who might not be familiar with the motivation:

Technically, `${ignition-math4_LIBRARIES}` will expand to `ignition-math4::ignition-math4` because the `ignition-math4-config.cmake` file will set `${ignition-math4_LIBRARIES}` to its imported target, causing the user to opaquely link to the imported target (...whether the user intended to or not).

Whichever approach you use, you'll be linking to the imported target, so that's good.

The key advantage to explicitly using the `ignition-math4::ignition-math4` is that with cmake there's always the annoying possibility that you might make a typo (like `${ignition-mth4_LIBRARIES}`) and then the typoed variable will expand to nothing, and you end up with a mysterious linking error later on, after compilation. When you use the `target::target` style, cmake itself will throw a build system error and point you at the culprit line in your `CMakeLists.txt` if you make a typo. This means the error is identified sooner in the build procedure, and it's pointed out to you more directly.

Then using `ignition-math${IGN_MATH_VER}::ignition-math${IGN_MATH_VER}` means that when you want to bump the version of your `ign-math` dependency, you only need to make a small change in one location.
content.html:
Just to add some commentary to this suggestion for anyone who might not be familiar with the motivation:

Technically, ${ignition-math4_LIBRARIES} will expand to ignition-math4::ignition-math4 because the ignition-math4-config.cmake file will set ${ignition-math4_LIBRARIES} to its imported target, causing the user to opaquely link to the imported target (...whether the user intended to or not).

Whichever approach you use, you'll be linking to the imported target, so that's good.

The key advantage to explicitly using the ignition-math4::ignition-math4 is that with cmake there's always the annoying possibility that you might make a typo (like ${ignition-mth4_LIBRARIES}) and then the typoed variable will expand to nothing, and you end up with a mysterious linking error later on, after compilation. When you use the target::target style, cmake itself will throw a build system error and point you at the culprit line in your CMakeLists.txt if you make a typo. This means the error is identified sooner in the build procedure, and it's pointed out to you more directly.

Then using ignition-math${IGN_MATH_VER}::ignition-math${IGN_MATH_VER} means that when you want to bump the version of your ign-math dependency, you only need to make a small change in one location.

content.raw: I looked at the console output and it seems like many of the warnings are coming from the protobuf system headers; perhaps they need to be included as system headers?
content.html: I looked at the console output and it seems like many of the warnings are coming from the protobuf system headers; perhaps they need to be included as system headers?

content.raw:
It seems that Visual Studio [doesn't let you differentiate](https://stackoverflow.com/a/2542006) between "system" headers and non-"system" headers.

Our protoc plugin class [very adeptly adds suppressions for these warnings](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/1bad2f95d5389492da789866bc1f9aa61576ee53/src/Generator.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#Generator.cc-84), but the suppression is happening at the `includes` insertion point, which comes immediately *after* the protobuf headers that are emitting the warnings. Based on the [protoc plugin documentation](https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/reference/cpp-generated#plugins) this is the earliest insertion point available. I'm not seeing any information on injecting code without using an insertion point, or creating our own insertion points, so it seems we won't be able to use the protoc plugin to handle this.

I'm realizing that my earlier attempt to suppress the warnings actually did work; it just didn't go far enough, because it (intentionally) doesn't impact the `*.cc` translation units like `Factory.cc`, `ign.cc`, and all the unit tests.

I think the next thing I'll try is, in all the files that we have control over, wrap any instances of `#include <google/protobuf/*.h>` and `#include <ignition/msgs/*.pb.h>` in MSVC warning suppression pragmas.

Ideally, in the long-term it would be nice if we could leverage the warning suppression system in `ign-common` for this, but that would add a dependency to `ign-msgs`, which is kind of a big change to make, so for the short-term I'll just write the pragmas manually.

I'm going to make a radical long-term proposal for us to chew on which we can discuss at a later date:

1. Merge `ign-common` and `ign-cmake`, renaming it all to something like `ign-common` or `ign-utility`
2. Anything in `ign-common` that has a dependency must be either taken over by another ignition project or made into its own ignition project

Things like cmake utilities, filesystem utilities, and warning suppression utilities would be easily shared across the ignition projects without needless dependencies.
content.html:
It seems that Visual Studio doesn't let you differentiate between "system" headers and non-"system" headers.

Our protoc plugin class very adeptly adds suppressions for these warnings, but the suppression is happening at the includes insertion point, which comes immediately after the protobuf headers that are emitting the warnings. Based on the protoc plugin documentation this is the earliest insertion point available. I'm not seeing any information on injecting code without using an insertion point, or creating our own insertion points, so it seems we won't be able to use the protoc plugin to handle this.

I'm realizing that my earlier attempt to suppress the warnings actually did work; it just didn't go far enough, because it (intentionally) doesn't impact the *.cc translation units like Factory.cc, ign.cc, and all the unit tests.

I think the next thing I'll try is, in all the files that we have control over, wrap any instances of #include <google/protobuf/*.h> and #include <ignition/msgs/*.pb.h> in MSVC warning suppression pragmas.

Ideally, in the long-term it would be nice if we could leverage the warning suppression system in ign-common for this, but that would add a dependency to ign-msgs, which is kind of a big change to make, so for the short-term I'll just write the pragmas manually.

I'm going to make a radical long-term proposal for us to chew on which we can discuss at a later date:

  1. Merge ign-common and ign-cmake, renaming it all to something like ign-common or ign-utility
  2. Anything in ign-common that has a dependency must be either taken over by another ignition project or made into its own ignition project

Things like cmake utilities, filesystem utilities, and warning suppression utilities would be easily shared across the ignition projects without needless dependencies.

content.raw: I suggest that you make a feature request for that radical proposal in the issue tracker for ignition-cmake.
content.html: I suggest that you make a feature request for that radical proposal in the issue tracker for ignition-cmake.

content.raw:
it looks like the protobuf find logic is broken for xenial and homebrew:

* https://build.osrfoundation.org//job/ignition_msgs-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/26
* https://build.osrfoundation.org//job/ignition_msgs-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/22

note that xenial uses protobuf 2.6.1 and homebrew uses 3.5.0
content.html:
it looks like the protobuf find logic is broken for xenial and homebrew:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org//job/ignition_msgs-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/26
  • https://build.osrfoundation.org//job/ignition_msgs-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64/22

note that xenial uses protobuf 2.6.1 and homebrew uses 3.5.0

content.raw:
That's because they're not using the correct branch of `ign-cmake`. We have our own mock protobuf package called `IgnProtobuf` that wraps the search for the real `Protobuf`. There are two motivations for this:

1. Older versions of Protobuf don't produce imported targets, which is something we need to ensure the `ignition` libraries are relocatable. `IgnProtobuf` will create these imported targets when they are missing, allowing us to be compatible with older installations of Protobuf.

2. The system-installed `FindProtobuf.cmake` module is not very smart, and so it will fail to recognize when a `ProtobufConfig.cmake` file is installed, which may cause us to miss out on important installation-specific target properties (this is VERY important for robust Windows support).

If we can instruct Jenkins to use the `FixSettingsForWindows` branch of `ign-cmake` (e.g. the way we do for Windows), these builds should work just fine.
content.html:
That's because they're not using the correct branch of ign-cmake. We have our own mock protobuf package called IgnProtobuf that wraps the search for the real Protobuf. There are two motivations for this:

  1. Older versions of Protobuf don't produce imported targets, which is something we need to ensure the ignition libraries are relocatable. IgnProtobuf will create these imported targets when they are missing, allowing us to be compatible with older installations of Protobuf.

  2. The system-installed FindProtobuf.cmake module is not very smart, and so it will fail to recognize when a ProtobufConfig.cmake file is installed, which may cause us to miss out on important installation-specific target properties (this is VERY important for robust Windows support).

If we can instruct Jenkins to use the FixSettingsForWindows branch of ign-cmake (e.g. the way we do for Windows), these builds should work just fine.
